B00080ZG10|4.0|\\"The Aviator\\" is a 2 3/4-hour extravaganza that follows 20 years in the life of multi-millionaire industrialist Howard Hughes, whose innovation and willingness to spend his considerable fortune on his passions changed the film and aviation industries in the United States. \\"The Aviator\\" captured 4 Academy Awards in 2005 and was nominated for about 100 awards by critical, professional, and other organizations in the US and the UK. Director Martin Scorsese has translated the most productive years in Hughes' life into a visual and dramatic tour de force, beginning as Hughes takes Hollywood by storm in 1927 and ending shortly after his victory over Senator Ralph Owen Brewster in securing international flight rights for TWA in 1947. The film ends before Hughes' days at RKO Studios.<br /><br />As \\"The Aviator\\" opens, Howard Hughes (Leonardo DiCaprio) is using his drill bit fortune to assemble the largest private air force in the world for his first film, \\"Hell's Angels\\", which became the most expensive film ever produced at the time. Hughes went on to make a couple of other notable films and to head RKO Studios, but \\"The Aviator\\" focuses on Hughes' aeronautical achievements more than his Hollywood career. Hughes' long relationship with Katharine Hepburn (Cate Blanchett), in whom he met his match, is depicted sympathetically and a bit wistfully, as if Hughes' life would have turned out differently had Kate stuck around. \\"The Aviator\\" takes us through Howard Hughes' ambition to build a passenger plane that would fly above the weather, his acquisition of TWA, his 1935 speed record, his record-breaking circumnavigation of the globe, his war contracts during World War II, and the crash that nearly killed him in 1946. The film's dramatic climax is probably the 1947 Senate hearings in which Hughes' battled Senator Brewster (Alan Alda) for TWA's right to compete with Pan Am Airways in international flights. We see Hughes' famous obsessive-compulsive behavior gradually become a corrosive force in his life, but the film ends before he became completely debilitated by it.<br /><br />Thanks to Leonardo DiCaprio, Howard Hughes' enthusiasm -indeed obsession- with aviation and his limitless ambition come across in every frame of \\"The Aviator\\". The supporting cast is all-star. Cate Blanchett seems to play Katharine Hepburn as a combination of the real woman and of her public image, which may or may not be the best approach, but it's what viewers will expect. John C. Reilly is Hughes' talented, long-suffering business manager, Noah Dietrich. Willem Dafoe, Jude Law, Gwen Stefani, and Ian Holm all have small roles. Kate Beckinsale is the glamourous actress Ava Gardner, Hughes' longtime friend. And Alec Baldwin is Pan Am's cunning president Juan Trippe. Dante Ferretti and Francesca Lo Schiavo's award-winning art direction and Robert Richardson's cinematography make \\"The Aviator\\" a visual delight. The incredible recreation of Los Angeles' Coconut Grove club, seen over the course of 3 decades, deserves special attention.<br /><br />The downside is that \\"The Aviator\\" is long and sometimes feels that way. The omission of most of Hughes' Hollywood relationships and his time at RKO may disappoint film buffs. And Scorsese's attempt to explain Hughes' obsessive-compulsive disorder by alluding to a childhood cholera epidemic is awkward. But Howard Hughes lived an extraordinary and eventful life, and \\"The Aviator\\" is a celebration of his achievements and a lament of his flaws. It's an entertaining epic of a larger-than-life American innovator.orce in his life, but the film ends before he became completely debilitated by it.     Thanks to Leonardo DiCaprio, Howard Hughes' enthusiasm -indeed obsession- with aviation and his limitless ambition come across in every frame of \\"The Aviator\\". The supporting cast is all-star. Cate Blanchett seems to play Katharine Hepburn as a combination of the real woman and of her public image, which may or may not be the best approach, but it's what viewers will expect. John C. Reilly is Hughes' talented, long-suffering business manager, Noah Dietrich. Willem Dafoe, Jude Law, Gwen Stefani, and Ian Holm all have small roles. Kate Beckinsale is the glamourous actress Ava Gardner, Hughes' longtime friend. And Alec Baldwin is Pan Am's cunning president Juan Trippe. Dante Ferretti and Francesca Lo Schiavo's award-winning art direction and Robert Richardson's cinematography make \\"The Aviator\\" a visual delight. The incredible recreation of Los Angeles' Coconut Grove club, seen over the course of 3 decades, deserves special attention.     The downside is that \\"The Aviator\\" is long and sometimes feels that way. The omission of most of Hughes' Hollywood relationships and his time at RKO may disappoint film buffs. And Scorsese's attempt to explain Hughes' obsessive-compulsive disorder by alluding to a childhood cholera epidemic is awkward. But Howard Hughes lived an extraordinary and eventful life, and \\"The Aviator\\" is a celebration of his achievements and a lament of his flaws. It's an entertaining epic of a larger-than-life American innovator.

B0007XT87G|5.0|My 15 year son and I just drove 150 miles to see Porcupine Tree and it was worth every penny and mile. Excellent sound and music in a small venue. Production work is solid, the music is moving, and the lyrics mysterious. Only wish they would have played Open Car from DeadWing or Strip the Soul from In Absentia in the concert. But Shallow (DW) and Blackest Eyes (IA) made up for it. Check out their schedule on Ticketmaster and go see this group. You'll be screaming for more encores...........

0385510454|5.0|The Broker was my first John Grisham novel, and I did enjoy the read. The story is about \\"The Broker\\", known as Joel Backman, who was a high powered legal consultant/Lawyer. Joel Backman let greed run his life, eventually leading to deaths of business associates and colleagues on a deal that went bad and sent nations into frenzy. Landing The Broker in prison for 6 years, resulting in an early pardon swayed heavily by the CIA's top dog Teddy Maynard's influence upon President Morgan, who just lost a landslide reelection and was on his way out of office. <br /> <br />The surprise pardon lands The Broker in Europe, while trying to take on a new identity and continuously look over his shoulder. When you read the book you'll learn a little bit of the Italian language, and you'll be captivated by each chapter. What The Broker is destined for, I won't spoil it for anyone, you'll have to read the book and learn for yourself. Overall, I enjoyed the story, and will read other Grisham Novels.
B00030590I|5.0|This is a fantastic telling of an epic tale of intrigue told from the perspectives of various characters. Each retelling features its own narrative style and visual/color keys. The viewer may slowly piece together the \\"true\\" amalgamation, but will you figure it out before the emperor? Style to burn, masterful battle sequences, great story, and a visually stunning array of set pieces make this a thoroughly enjoyable film. Don't expect a fight-a-minute-thrill-ride or an overly obvious plot line. Also, be aware of the strong undertones of Chinese political sensibility (PRC). As grand as anything Hollywood can crank out, but with sophistication, and staggering beauty and style. A visual meal for the eyes and mind that will satisfy long after it is consumed.

B00005JMJ4|5.0|Through a subtle story and script, a floaty and dreamlike cinematographical style, and the underlying theme of humour and love, this film captures the feeling of being \\"lost\\" - literally  and figuratively. \\"Lost in Translation\\" captures the essence of what the main characters are experiencing during their stay in Tokyo. The movie encourages viewers to feel as lost as John Harris (Bill Murray), an impatient and washed-up American actor who's lost touch with himself and his family, or relate to the lonely young twenty-something wife, Charlotte (Scarlett Johansson), who is intelligent yet unsure about what to do with her life and finds herself in Tokyo because she followed her young and energetic (yet lacking a certain depth) photographer husband on a business trip. John and Charlotte meet at the highly polished hotel they are both staying at and form a unique bond during their week in the impossibly foreign, overwhelmingly urban, hectic and dream-like surroundings of Tokyo. Each scene captures the essence of being both lost in one's surroundings and in one's self. The scenes are designed to embody the sometimes embarassing and funny things that can happen in an unfamiliar culture, or simply capture the powerful bond that Charlotte and John share during their time in Tokyo. No, it's not a romance between Charlotte and John, but they do form a certain love and deep understanding during their week's stay and both begin to find their way a bit easier after meeting each other. Murray and Johansson were a pleasure to watch in this film and very convincing when capturing the essence of the bond that their two characters share. Not to mention a subtle and cool soundtrack, a floaty cinematographic style, understated humour, and best of all, a sweet yet appropriate ending, this movie is certainly one of the best films of the year.
B0000025P9|3.0|\\"Toto IV\\" was a huge smash hit, but it's REALLY stretching it to call it a classic. <br /> <br />\\"Rosanna\\" and \\"Africa\\" are two of the most ubiquitously-familiar songs of the '80s--they're certainly catchy, and David Paich's craftsmanship is impressive, plus it was wise to give at least portions of the lead vocals to Steve Lukather and Paich respectively. <br /> <br />Also, Steve Porcaro does get in one of his characteristically sincere-sounding reflective ballads with the enjoyable \\"It's A Feeling\\".   <br /> <br />By and large though, the music is a case of style-over-substance, with obnoxiously-flashy synthesizer flourishes, lame-brained lyrics, and the ultra-slick, professional-yet-rote vocals of Bobby Kimball.  The band does get a really good groove going on \\"Waiting For Your Love\\", but then Kimball's annoyingly insincere vocals come in and drag the song down.  \\"Make Believe\\" brings back the doo-wop flavor of the first album's big hit \\"Hold The Line\\", but not as effectively.  Lukather's \\"I Won't Hold You Back\\" is a reasonably tasteful ballad, but it's simply dull. <br /> <br />\\"Toto IV\\" is proof positive that it takes more than just great chops to make a great album.

B0000017CA|5.0|The term \\"underground classic\\" is one that gets thrown around quite a bit, but Acid Bath's When the Kite String Pops is one recording that can lay almost undisputed claim to the title.  Unfortunately, the underground is just as full of ripoffs and one-trick ponies as the mainstream (well, ok, maybe not quite that full), but Acid Bath were one band that managed to stand alone with a distinctive sound that was decidedly ahead of its time in 1994.  Between their stunningly tight and efficient musicianship and their flair for variety, one can only imagine what these guys would've accomplished if not for their early demise.  When the Kite String Pops is a highly potent slab of controlled substance-fuelled death rock at its most discordantly evil, with songs chock full of tempo and vocal changes, but its unpredictability only serves to enhance the harrowing mood that persists througout its running time.  At times brutally scathing, at other times hauntingly melodic, but always profoundly unsettling, this album is a psycho nightmare of epic proportions, with its fourteen pieces of nightmarish sonic impressionism pushing it to about an hour of nearly nonstop punishment.<br /><br />Although Acid Bath did show some superficial resemblances to such southern metal brethren as Soilent Green and Crowbar, their sound was still their own creation, one that liberally incorporated elements of sludge, thrash, grind, and rock.  Few bands have managed to convert angst and disaffection into great music-Neurosis and Godflesh are prominent exceptions-because such emotions tend to result in whiny, self-indulgent tripe, but Acid Bath succeeded where others have failed because their focus never deviated from creativity and songwriting.  It also doesn't hurt that the band had Dax Riggs, easily one of the most distinctive metal vocalists of recent years, out in front.  Befitting Acid Bath's abrasive sound and nihilistic lyrics, Dax alternated between an acidic, face-melting howl and a cleaner singing voice that managed to be every bit as disturbing as his more \\"metal\\" vocals.<br /><br />While the overall mood of this album is one of menacing rawness and insanity, that doesn't mean Acid Bath weren't methodical in their approach, as the precision and eclecticism to be found here are uniformly impressive.  Just check out the opener Blue, which effortlessly mixes slow, grinding torment with head-banging thrash-metal passages and plenty of Dax's doomy singing.  From there, the album rarely lets up, as there are a couple of downcast acoustic numbers in the form of Scream of the Butterfly and What Color is Death, but those are definitely exceptions to the rule.  Most of the songs on When the Kite String Pops are musical and emotional roller coasters, filled with intricate, oscillating riff patterns, frantic drumming, and malevolently pounding basslines.  If forced at gunpoint to pick a favorite tune I'd have to go with the utterly unsettling Jezebel, but every song here is fully realized and brilliantly executed, a rarity for an album with this many tracks.  If you're into extreme music, this album is a must-buy.  And even if you're not, and you just want to hear something with some true emotion and intelligence behind it, you should still give it a shot.  Demented as it may seem on the surface, in a music world dominated by brainless mainstream tripe, When the Kite String Pops managed to rise to the level of art.er singing voice that managed to be every bit as disturbing as his more \\"metal\\" vocals.   <br /> <br />While the overall mood of this album is one of menacing rawness and insanity, that doesn't mean Acid Bath weren't methodical in their approach, as the precision and eclecticism to be found here are uniformly impressive.  Just check out the opener Blue, which effortlessly mixes slow, grinding torment with head-banging thrash-metal passages and plenty of Dax's doomy singing.  From there, the album rarely lets up, as there are a couple of downcast acoustic numbers in the form of Scream of the Butterfly and What Color is Death, but those are definitely exceptions to the rule.  Most of the songs on When the Kite String Pops are musical and emotional roller coasters, filled with intricate, oscillating riff patterns, frantic drumming, and malevolently pounding basslines.  If forced at gunpoint to pick a favorite tune I'd have to go with the utterly unsettling Jezebel, but every song here is fully realized and brilliantly executed, a rarity for an album with this many tracks.  If you're into extreme music, this album is a must-buy.  And even if you're not, and you just want to hear something with some true emotion and intelligence behind it, you should still give it a shot.  Demented as it may seem on the surface, in a music world dominated by brainless mainstream tripe, When the Kite String Pops managed to rise to the level of art.

6305144176|5.0|A great movie, loosely based on the Nam tour of the real Adrian Cronauer, as others have said. <br /> <br />Adrian is a respected member of the Vietnam Vet community and a number of Vet friends have mentioned his take on the movie - 'If I'd done half of that stuff, Id have ended up in Leavenworth'. <br /> <br />The movie is both a Robin Williams vehicle and a look at the first major build-up in the War itself. As for it being a 'police action', the irony was not lost on entertainers like Bob Hope, who often greeted his Nam audiences with \\"Hello Advisors!\\" even when there were more than 500,000 troops in Vietnam. <br /> <br />In many ways this excellent movie was the first real indication of the caliber of Robin Williams as an actor. He simply shines in this role and it led to a well-deserved Oscar nomination and on to greater things. <br /> <br />Highly recommended.

0142000663|2.0|While Steinbeck does, in the end, manage to convey an image of a portion of America during the Great Depression, it was an image confused by wordiness. The chapters describing the family where extremely slow moving, with dialogue and descriptions that would go on for pages, but which did not have any real point in the context of the story, and, perhaps more importantly given one of the main purposes of this novel, was not necessary to give the reader a \\"feel\\" of the times.  This overabundance of irrelevent information detracts from the story, in that it makes it difficult for the reader to fully submerse his-/herself in the story and, in the end, obscures the portrait of America at this time, as the reader is given so many details, that they begin to run over each other. Essentially it is a portrait that is completely lacking a frame, and this lack of a frame- or a context for all of the details, leads to a very confused image and story.<br /><br />I did not loathe the entire book, and even enjoyed some of the intermediate chapters describing the country as a whole (I particularly liked the one about the used car dealership), as I felt that these were well written, and the most concise.  Furthermore, the symbolism was rather good, but again, overdone, as was Steinbeck's use of naturalism.<br /><br />However, the main plot line, the Joads' migration, was overly convuluted and, after the umptenth tragic mishap, left me utterly apathetic to the fate of the family or their plight, especially since there seemed to be a tendency to \\"kill off\\" or otherwise subject the characters to tragic fates before they had been developed to the point that I actually cared what happened to them-- that they became more than just characters in a book (with the sole exception of Casey).  When I reached the end of the book, I found myself asking-- \\"what was the point?\\" Steinbeck dragged this family through the depths of hell, and yet it was done in such a clinical fashion that it lacked the human and emotional essence needed to make it be for a point, or even just that no one should have to suffer so pointlessly.  One acknowledges that (hopefully) already on a logical level, but this book failed to invest it with any kind of emotional level, despite the seven page conversations.  Having read \\"Of Mice and Men,\\" I know that Steinbeck can do better.  I was decidedly NOT apathetic to the fate of Lennie and George.  Even with allowances made for the different purposes of the stories, I cannot give a great deal of credit to a story seems pointless (except maybe post-modernism :-)cked the human and emotional essence needed to make it be for a point, or even just that no one should have to suffer so pointlessly. There is nothing like a row of hot horn players in tight mini-skirts that really know how to blow their horns. It was an honour to see him. <br /> <br />If you get this album and you hear a Sam Kinnison scream \\"ow-owwwww!!\\" between songs...well...that's me. <br /> <br />After the show my friend and I went back down to the Tenderloin, got us some Jack, smoked both brown and grenn and sat on the sidewalk next each other trying to bum change for the eff of it. <br /> <br />Bumming change doesn't work well when you're having a good time. <br /> <br />      <br /> <br />
0060920084|5.0|It was the coffee stain that first caught my attention. I was walking out of the bookstore and there sat a book with a coffee ring on it. I paused and smiled. The book looked like it came from my desk, coffee stain and all. I smiled at the yellow roadside sign with the red arrow. I had observed many of these as I crisscrossed the United States over the last several years. With all these associations, how could I not pause and begin reading?<br /><br />A few minutes later I walked out of the bookstore with a smile and the book under my arm. Here was a kindred spirit, a sojourner lost in his own country, navigating his way through all that was familiar and strange.<br /><br />Mr. Bryson encircles the United States in a large figure eight with Des Moines, Iowa in the center, as it should be. He covers every region of the nation, aghast and agape at what he sees. He describes it in dry prose punctuated by laugh-out-loud comments. Mr. Bryson is pithy and riotously funny.<br /><br />If you are not planning on traversing the byways of the U.S. soon, by all means read this book now. If you have a trip planned, hold off reading this. Have your own experience, then pick up this book and see how many times your paths crossed. You'll laugh out loud too.
B000001DYD|4.0|This is the very first CD-format music I ever bought, at the tender age of 13, and my father promptly told me how annoying and inappropriate it was as soon as he heard it. Ironically, the first time I saw PJ Harvey was on a late-night episode of that old TV show \\"Beavis and Butthead\\"; they played the video for \\"Man-Size\\" where she just sits on a stool in her underwear and fidgets while singing the song. It was love! Naturally I became a huge PJ fan and proceeded to buy all her albums...until \\"Is This Desire?\\", when I kind of fell out of the artist's loop. I really enjoy the bare, stripped-down quality of this CD, as well as \\"4-Track Demos\\", which is even more reduced. It often seems that the more albums an artist puts out, the more produced the songs tend to seem, and PJ is no exception. Originality still prevails, but the sound is different these days.  <br />One of my favorites is the howling \\"Legs\\", which sends a creepy shiver up your spine the first (and almost every) time you hear it. It's stark and empty yet full of really overwhelming emotion - much like the jacket photography on this album.  <br />I recommend this one and her first album \\"Dry\\" - \\"Water\\" and \\"Plants and Rags\\" are great ones off that album. Another album which doesn't come up easily on a PJ search is \\"Dance Hall at Louse Point\\" which she put out with guitarist John Parish. \\"That Was My Veil\\" (track 4)is one of the most haunting and beautiful acoustic songs I've heard in years.
B000002GJH|5.0|This would be the definitive work. This is, perhaps, the best CD I've ever heard. Perhaps it's because this album was a labor of love. Perhaps it's because Chris Cornell is one of the best songwriters and singers in the history of rock. Perhaps it's so wonderful because it is truly an amalgamation of everything that defined the Seattle music scene in that era. It's probably a mixture of all these things. <br />In case the other reviewers haven't enlightened you, this album was the eulogy to Andrew Wood, lead singer of Mother Love Bone, and penned by Chris Cornell and former MLB member Stone Gossard. The idea began with \\"Say Hello 2 Heaven\\" and \\"Reach Down\\", both directly about Wood, and written by Cornell. When Cornell showed the demos to the other members of Mother Love Bone, the project just evolved. <br />Usually, my mood dictates what music I listen to. This album, however, defines my mood. When I put it in the player, I can't stop listening to it. I've had this CD for...6, 7 years? And it never gets old. Ever. Let's break it down track by track (keep in mind that my rating system, out of 10, is relative to other songs ON THIS ALBUM, not compared to the world at large, they are all 10/10 when compared to everything else): <br /> <br />1. Say Hello 2 Heaven; undoubtedly, this is the best song on the album. It is filled with so much emotion, and it shines throughout. The love in this song can be felt both in the lyrics and the way Cornell sings it, he was at the absolute top of his game here. 10/10 <br /> <br />2. Reach Down; I did not realize that this song was 11 and a half minutes long until I'd listened to it about 10 times. This song is heavily driven by the music, not as much by Cornell's lyrics. The solos and subsequent jam session that lasts about 7 minutes are sublime, you lose yourself in the music. This song is an incredible work of art, the lyrics and music are beautiful, but it still isn't my favorite. 9/10 <br /> <br />3. Hunger Strike; the most commonly heard \\"radio song\\" from this collection, it also features Eddie Vedder on backing vocals. Some people are annoyed by the extended repetition of \\"I'm goin' hungry\\", but personally I love the way Vedder's voice melds with Cornell's. They dance around each other, melodically. This is also the most \\"mainstream\\" song on the CD, not as bluesy or experimental as say, \\"Reach Down\\" or \\"Four-Walled World\\". 8/10 <br /> <br />4. Pushing Forward Back; the most driven song on the album, this song has the most edge as well. It's apparent that Cornell sings this one from his heart, and although it's brief, discusses how he fought with his mother. This song marks a shift in the CD, from the very emotional first three songs about Wood to more introspective songs Cornell wrote about himself, but wouldn't fit on a a Soundgarden album. 8/10 <br /> <br />5. Call Me a Dog; what is this song about? Your guess is as good as mine. This is, personally, my least favorite track on the album, and one of two I'll skip at times (the other is \\"Your Savior\\", but for different reasons). \\"Call Me a Dog\\" most likely relates to Wood...but then who can tell? It's oddly placed after such a driving song like \\"Pushin' Forward Back\\". 6/10 <br /> <br />6. Times of Trouble; one of the best songs on the CD, this song mixes mellow blues with mind-blowing and heart-wrenching vocal fury from Cornell. The subject material is heroin, and the addiction. The tempo of the song mirrors the content, as it starts slow (as if you were taking the drug), and it ends in violent splendor, as if Cornell were talking to heroin addicts everywhere, telling them to hold on. The last line is especially moving, musically, the way Cornell screams \\"...if somebody loved you and left you for dead...\\" always gives me goosebumps. 10/10 <br /> <br />7. Wooden Jesus; another fantastic song, probably my second favorite behind \\"Say Hello 2 Heaven\\", mainly for the way Cornell sings it. It's a commentary on religion in America, specificallyCatholicism (Cornell was raised Catholic, something he struggled with), but it discusses how much faith they place in figurines to save them from their troubles. He mocks people who try to bargain with God, and the tone of the song is both sardonic and regretful. Cornell lets his vocals explode toward the end of the song, and it is miraculous- you can heart the bitterness dripping from his voice. 10/10 <br /> <br />8. Your Savior; another religious song, continuing well the theme of \\"Wooden Jesus\\". Cornell sings of his digust for the evangelical types who \\"whisper his tragic end\\". He accepts their criticism and their complaints, but he does not want what they offer- their savior (Jesus, for the inept). I sometimes skip this song because I don't feel it fits musically with \\"Wooden Jesus\\", so I sometimes move to \\"Four-Walled World\\". Still, its an excellent song, the angriest on the CD (despite not being as hard as \\"Pushin' Forward Back\\"). 8/10 <br /> <br />9. Four-Walled World; I have mixed feelings on this song. Sometimes I love it, and sometimes I love it less (I'd be lying if I ever said I disliked it). It has a strange cadence and tempo, and like the previous two songs is very much spoken from Cornell's heart. Ostensibly, it speaks of a lover who has left him, but it is more about Cornell's struggle inside his own world, or his \\"cell\\" as he calls it. It is still an excellent song, the most bluesy on the CD, rivaling \\"Call Me a Dog\\", but much better presented. The end, once again, features about two solid minutes of Cornell destroying his vocal cords in a delicious manner, and you can feel his frustration with himself. 9/10 <br /> <br />10. All Night Thing; an excellent end to an excellent album. \\"She motioned to me/that she wanted to leave...\\" The organ-thing in the background is a bit strange sounding, but it follows the heavy snare line, both led by Cornell's dominating voice, very much the centerpiece of this song. The song is slow and smooth, and bring a sense of closure and contemplation to the work. You can feel Cornell pacing the streets of Seattle thinking about this song, forming it in his mind, as he sees people shack up in bars across the city. 8/10 <br /> <br />When all is said and done, this is the best album ever written, if for no other reason than the emotion so readily visible (or audible, I suppose). I am addicted to Cornell's voice, and this is him at the very tip top of his vocal career. No one on the Seattle scene or anywhere else could match the raw emotion that man brings to a song. I say that this CD is the perfect encapsulation of the Seattle music scene in the early 90s because it is truly a \\"supergroup\\". The men in this band had played with every major act in the city at one point or another, between the five (occasionally six) of them. The awe-inspiring power of this music made me go out and buy a Mother Love Bone CD, just to see where these wunderkinds came from. As a sidenote, its more like Queen mixed with Nirvana than it is Soundgarden or Pearl Jam. But hey, RIP Andrew Wood, and I'm sure he's thankful that his death spawned such fantastic music. <br /> <br />Everyone should go out and buy this CD immediately, for the betterment of mankind.
B00082IJ08|4.0|Note, before you read on, just know that I myself do not like the Rap genre. It doesn't appeal to me and I just never really liked it. <br /> <br />Even with that though, I completely LOVE this Album. One of its quirks being that there was an over usage of rap in \\"Demon Days\\" as opposed to their first CD, but even with that, this Album executes everything greatly.  <br /> <br />Unlike the first CD, alot of the songs go right into the other. It gives the CD a great flow and it's very enjoyable when listening to it on your car or CD player.  <br /> <br />The only thing that really stopped me from giving this CD 5 stars is the poorly executed rap, mainly in the song \\"Dirty Harry\\". B0001EFTVA|5.0|Three homeless people find a baby in the trash.  Now they have to decide what to do with her - keep her, give her over to the cops or try to find her mother.  As the three try to decide what they need to do the three people end up exploring love, life and the meaning of it all.  It is very touching, with lots of humor and heart in each moment. B00080ZG10|4.0|Howard Hughes created aviation history, pushed the film industry to new heights and generally excelled at whatever interested him. He flew high on wings of wax. Ultimately, he got a little too close to the sun and as the wings fell apart his anxieties consumed in resulting in Obsessive Compulsive Disorder taking control of his life.  Obsessive compulsive disorder can make an individual feel as if their world is both completely out of control and completely ordered. Someone with OCD requires constant reassurance which is why they are constantly checking the door to see if it is locked, obsessively stacking things, obsessively counting and fight irrational thoughts that threaten their structured existence. It's a symptom of a much larger anxiety. Howard Hughes was a risk taker something that you frequently see in people with OCD but the consequence is a worsening of their OCD symptoms and anxieties. As Hughes fame increased, his need to push the envelope increased and his OCD increasing took control of his life. \\"The Aviator\\" is much more than a movie about a man with anxiety and mental illness. Scorsese fashions a film about a man with an endless stream of ideas fighting the demons of mental illness at every turn and, ultimately, losing the battle. Of course we don't see the end of the battle we just experience Hughes in his prime; when we first meet him he's shooting \\"Hell's Angels\\" a Hollywood epic that cost the unheard of amount of $4 million in the early 30's. The film revolutionized action films and nearly ruined Hughes. \\"The Aviator\\" focuses on the difficulties that Hughes has with his OCD and how it both hampers and pushes his life forward. By the conclusion we see a hint of the Hughes that locked himself in his hotel room in Las Vegas and wore tissue boxes on his feet.<br /><br />Hughes had affairs with actresses (Katherine Hepburn in her Oscar winning role), Ava Gardner (Kate Beckinsale), Terry Wright all the while battling corporate giants that want him to fail; Pam Am's Juan Tripp (Alec Baldwin in a wonderful, oily performance), a corrupt senator (Alan Alda), studio moguls and film censor Breen (Edward Hermann). Stocked with wonderful cameos (Jude Law plays Errol Flynn, \\"Star Trek: The Next Generation\\"'s Brent Spiner as plane designer Robert Gross, Ian Holm, Willem DaFoe, singers Rufus, Loudon, and Martha Wainwright, \\"Six Feet Under\\" star Frances Conroy) Scorsese's epic tries to make sense of Hughes within the context of how he defined himself (much like \\"Raging Bull\\" did). A stylishly directed film, Scorsese pulls out all the stops to make \\"The Aviator\\" visually ravishing whether it be his imitation of the Technicolor look for each decade covered or the dazzling juxtaposition ironic images, Scorsese is at the top of his game here. Editor Thelma Schoonmaker provides Scorsese with ample support with her brilliant editing. Although overlooked by Oscar by the more timely \\"Million Dollar Baby\\", I have no doubt that time will be much kinder to Scorsese's more ambitious biopic epic. Despite criticism to the contrary, John Logan's fine script may not dig as deeply as some critics like but it's the subtext Scorsese, Logan and DiCaprio provide that may this film much richer than it appears on the surface. While there's outstanding performances from the entire cast, DiCaprio's performance anchors and dominates the film as it should. He brings Hughes to life in the film and his rewarding collaboration with Scorsese continues to be fruitful more so here than in the deeply flawed \\"Gangs of New York\\".<br /><br />A beautiful, sharp, vivid transfer receives as much bit space as possible with only the alternate commentary track by director Martin Scorsese with occasional contributions from producer/director Michael Mann and editor Thelma Schooner taking up additional space on the first disc. I'd suggest that film fans keep in mind that the smeared look that you see early on textured surfaces is intentional as the digital master has been grain reduced from start to finish. This was, again, designed to resemble many of the textures seen in early 2 strip Technicolor films. Likewise, you'll notice that the peas on Hughes' plate appear almost turquoise representing the reproduction capabilities of early Technicolor. You'll notice that the color becomes fuller, richer as the film progresses presenting the advancement from early 3 strip to later, mature 3 strip Technicolor. The sound is quite good using the 5.1 Dolby Digital Surround format in a number of subtle but important ways throughout. Dialog and music are crystal clear.<br /><br />This flawed masterpiece is equaled by a great set of extras on disc two. \\"Making the Aviator\\" is a standard making of featurette where everybody praises everyone else. There's also a deleted scene where Howard tells Ava about a car accident (although the cut scenes involving Amelia Earhart are not included. Perhaps we'll get this in a deluxe expanded director's edition). The History Channel documentary Howard Hughes focuses much more on the technical innovations he introduced including the changes he made in the world of aviation, satellite technology. Hughes biographer Pat Broeske provides interesting insights as to what occurred in his life that made him the way he was. James Steele author of \\"Howard Hughes: His life and his Madness\\" points out how the Hughes empire was build on the oil drilling bit his father designed. Little of the time in the documentary focuses on Hughes movie making. George Marrett author of \\"Howard Hughes: Aviator\\" discusses how Hughes and his collaborators broke new ground with air speed records and unique airplane designs.<br /><br />\\"The Role of Howard Hughes in Aviation History\\" is an original documentary on the achievements that Hughes and his company did to push the envelope of aviation. It's not a conventional biography obviously. We learn from Hughes author George Marrett about Hughes' love of flying. Including interviews with DiCaprio and others associated with the film, it incorporates footage from \\"The Aviator\\" but also manages to tell Hughes role in changing air travel and breaking speed records.<br /><br />\\"OCD\\" focuses on the obsession compulsive disorder that drove him and relieved his anxieties and unstated fears. Actor Leonard DiCaprio discusses the research that he did for the role including contacting OCD expert Dr. Jeffrey Schwartz at the UCLA medical school. OCD is a disorder in the brain where bothersome thoughts intrude into the individuals thoughts without prompting creating fear. The compulsion is the behavior one does again and again to try and control the feeling. There's an interview with someone who has OCD who helped DiCaprio focus the compulsive behavior, the way it's said correctly to help pull it all together. The intrusive thoughts are caused by a chemical balance in the brain. There's also a panel discussion on OCD featuring Scorsese, DiCaprio and Hughes widow Terry Wright.<br /><br />\\"An Evening with Leonardo DiCaprio and Alan Alda\\" although a promo piece actually provides considerable insight into the characters they played, Hughes and the film itself. DiCaprio discusses how his early interest in the subject brought both Michael Mann and Scorsese on board.<br /><br />Scorsese's animated commentary continues to be a highlight of any DVD he's a part of. When Scorsese slows down a bit Schoonmaker steps in to discuss the editing, the craft of filmmaking and some of the more challenging scenes in the movie. Mann occasionally jumps in. Since he was the director originally attached to this project (he dropped it because he had already made two films based on real people \\"Ali\\" and \\"The Insider\\" back-to-back and wanted a break) and became a producer his comments are also quite interesting as well particularly about Scorsese uses two color Technicolor, three strip Technicolor and other devices to plant the film firmly in the various decades they took place in.<br /><br /> Although it might not be a masterpiece in the same mold as \\"Raging Bull\\", \\"The Aviator\\" is one of the best films that Scorsese has made in the latter part of his career. Heck, I'd argue that it does belong with his best films; it's just a different sort of film from what most of Scorsese's fans are used to. It has much more in common with \\"New York, New York\\" than with \\"Taxi Driver\\" although there are also elements of the latter film represented in Hughes obsessive personality. I hate comparing movies but far and away \\"The Aviator\\" is a much deeper, richer, ambitious and intelligent film than Clint Eastwood's topical but overrated \\"Million Dollar Baby\\". Both films have their merit but the fact that the Academy overlooked this film (as they did Annette Benning for \\"Being Julia) is a crime and continues to demonstrate how the Academy makes the easy choice when it comes to complex and intelligent filmmaking.Caprio and others associated with the film, it incorporates footage from \\"The Aviator\\" but also manages to tell Hughes role in changing air travel and breaking speed records.  <br /> <br />\\"OCD\\" focuses on the obsession compulsive disorder that drove him and relieved his anxieties and unstated fears. Actor Leonard DiCaprio discusses the research that he did for the role including contacting OCD expert Dr. Jeffrey Schwartz at the UCLA medical school. OCD is a disorder in the brain where bothersome thoughts intrude into the individuals thoughts without prompting creating fear. The compulsion is the behavior one does again and again to try and control the feeling. There's an interview with someone who has OCD who helped DiCaprio focus the compulsive behavior, the way it's said correctly to help pull it all together. The intrusive thoughts are caused by a chemical balance in the brain. There's also a panel discussion on OCD featuring Scorsese, DiCaprio and Hughes widow Terry Wright.  <br /> <br />\\"An Evening with Leonardo DiCaprio and Alan Alda\\" although a promo piece actually provides considerable insight into the characters they played, Hughes and the film itself. DiCaprio discusses how his early interest in the subject brought both Michael Mann and Scorsese on board.  <br /> <br />Scorsese's animated commentary continues to be a highlight of any DVD he's a part of. When Scorsese slows down a bit Schoonmaker steps in to discuss the editing, the craft of filmmaking and some of the more challenging scenes in the movie. Mann occasionally jumps in. Since he was the director originally attached to this project (he dropped it because he had already made two films based on real people \\"Ali\\" and \\"The Insider\\" back-to-back and wanted a break) and became a producer his comments are also quite interesting as well particularly about Scorsese uses two color Technicolor, three strip Technicolor and other devices to plant the film firmly in the various decades they took place in.  <br /> Although it might not be a masterpiece in the same mold as \\"Raging Bull\\", \\"The Aviator\\" is one of the best films that Scorsese has made in the latter part of his career. Heck, I'd argue that it does belong with his best films; it's just a different sort of film from what most of Scorsese's fans are used to. It has much more in common with \\"New York, New York\\" than with \\"Taxi Driver\\" although there are also elements of the latter film represented in Hughes obsessive personality. I hate comparing movies but far and away \\"The Aviator\\" is a much deeper, richer, ambitious and intelligent film than Clint Eastwood's topical but overrated \\"Million Dollar Baby\\". Both films have their merit but the fact that the Academy overlooked this film (as they did Annette Benning for \\"Being Julia) is a crime and continues to demonstrate how the Academy makes the easy choice when it comes to complex and intelligent filmmaking.    <br />
B0002VKZL6|5.0|Many of these reviews hit on the same point.  At first listen, this effort didnt knock you down.  Not a BROTHERS IN ARMS. No instant gem. B000002UB6|4.0|Let it Be has been unfairly maligned. After years of studio experimentation and trickery, the Beatles attempted to get back to basics with this album, and they succeed tremendously. Unfortunately, this music was recorded during the nadir of group relations, and the album is suffused with hints of the impending split. Nevetheless there are great songs and performances. <br />   I have two gripes though. Am I the only Beatles fan who thinks Across the Universe sucks? I just don't understand the appeal of the song. I know Lennon thought highly of it, but the melody is weak, the lyrics are juvenile and the vocal is tentative at best. I can't even listen to it; the Past Masters version is a little better. Secondly, The Long and Winding Road is dreadful in any incarnation. Maybe the Spector treatment ruined the song for me, but it's just too maudlin. Conversely, Dig a Pony is a woefully underrated gem: great guitar riff and lead by George, spirited, vocal by John and beautiful harmony by Paul, and Ringo holding it together with power and finesse. And before anyone complains about the the lyrics being nonsense, go listen to I Am the Walrus! <br />   The title track, is of course, an all-time Beatles classic. Has Paul ever sounded so smooth and soulful? I get the feeling that he was learning about gospel music from Billy Preston, who played keyboards on the sessions. George's solo is just killer, more trenchant and emotional than the one featured on the single version. This is a towering achievement in the Beatles' canon. <br />   Two of Us, I Got a Feeling, I Me Mine, and For You Blue are also very good. One After 909 is an early rocker that dated back to their Cavern Club days and was performed with gusto on  the rooftop gig, as was the great version of Get Back which appears here. Maggie Mae is probably in keeping with the Get Back concept, with its references to Liverpool. So while not a great track, it's not a complete throwaway either - plus it's only 38 seconds. Dig it is quite enjoyable also. Again it's very short, a snippet of a very long jam. The Beatles are having fun, and John was having fun free-associating. If you think about it, Dig It, Maggie Mae and the spoken asides that pepper the album are pioneering examples of the annoying practice of using skits, intros, outros and interludes in so much modern music. I think Billy Preston was the first \\"featuring....\\" on the single Get Back.  <br />   Let It Be is a better album than Sgt. Pepper. Maybe not the best recording/production, but it has better songs and better conceptual unity. It better illustrated the magic that occurred when all four Beatles were in the same room together....or on the same roof!

0312199066|5.0|I knew almost nothing about Gene Cernan before I read this book. It's a shame it took me so long to discover him, because Cernan is a compelling and entertaining storyteller, as well as a very typical example of what he himself calls the \\"macho fighter pilot\\" ethos that Tom Wolfe chronicled in The Right Stuff. Compared to several other books that I've read about the U.S. space program in the 1960s-70s (Aldrin, Shepherd/Slayton, Kranz), Cernan gives us an a more objective and unflinching picture of the jockeying for flight assignments and the clashes between strong, ambitious personalities that roiled NASA's Astronaut Office. He also speaks frankly about the disastrous effects that the demands of being an astronaut had on several \\"picture-perfect\\" astronaut families, including his own. All of these were unmentionable topics at the time, and are still not talked about frequently today. However, the book is not only about the negative aspects of the space program. Cernan spends quite a bit of time describing the wonders that he experienced orbiting the earth and walking on the moon. Highly recommended.
0930289234|5.0|I picked this up to read on a plane just to kill time. I was expecting the run of the mill graphic novel. What I got was a story so in depth, engrossing, and touching that I could not put it down. This was definitely a welcomed change from the technical books I normally read. The story of the Watchmen actually forced me to feel for the characters in the story, and understand their motives. You grow to respect the characters as more than 2 dimensional storyboards. In this world of masked vigilantes driven to dish out justice as a novelty hobby, they are faced with the concept of a real life superhero changing their very existence, making them obsolete. The younger generation just cannot let go of the concept of dressing up and fighting crime and continue despite the appearance of the \\"God Among Men\\". Some do it because they are forced to, some get sexual gratification out of it, some are driven by deep psychological issues brought on by troubled childhoods, and a very small handful do it to make things right. The story has more twists and turns, and really pulls the reader into their universe, and forces them to wonder \\"Who watches the Watchers\\" when they go beyond the line. Even if you are not into the whole comic genre, this is a story that will move you.

B000067J1H|5.0|I believe that movies are made to entertain. I basically enjoy all kinds of movies...action, comedy, romance, sci-fi, thrillers etc. and I rarely criticize a movie because I know the effort put in to make a movie. But every once in a while, a movie comes out that does more than entertain, it makes you think, it makes you question and it changes your perception about various things. Well, Fight Club is one of those movies. I have watched this movie many many many times and it never fails to astound me. This is in my opinion, one of the best movies to come out of Hollywood.     It is basically about this guy, only known as the Narrator who is a white collar employee, working a 9 to 5 job, has his own apartment and his own collection of branded items. Sounds familiar? It's not surprising many of us can relate to this guy. Anyhow, even with all these material items, he finds his life unsatisfying, he feels that something is lacking. Because of this problem, he suffers from insomnia. He finds solace in attending those self-help sessions but soon meets another faker, Marla. The presence of another faker makes him uncomfortable and the sessions don't work for him anymore. It is then that he meets Tyler Durden, this cool, smart talking dude in a plane. This guy intrigued him and when the Narrator returns to find his apartment burnt, he turns to Tyler for help. From there on, this movie spirals to dizzying heights, with the creation of Fight Club by the Narrator and Tyler, and later what seems to be a takeover of Fight Club by Tyler leaving the Narrator clueless about what's going on.     I really have to say this movie really fascinated me so much with it's intelligent ideas and dialogue, partly because deep in my heart, on some level...I can relate to the character, and although I don't agree with everything that is said, it does make me think and how many movies can do that? Fight Club to me, represents our lives in a twisted way. It challenges us to think about things inlife, for example our view of success. Does working a boring job to pay for things we don't need a success? Do you experience fulfillment or do you think you're wasting your life away? (...)  Everybody involved in this movie did a fantastic job but extra credit has to go to the director, writer and the actors. David Fincher has come a long way from directing music videos for Madonna. I am a huge fan and I've seen all his work, Aliens 3, Se7en, The Game and more recently Panic Room. No one but him can create an environment of decay and desperation in this movie that just grabs you. Kudos to the actors involved too. Everyone was perfectly cast. The talented Edward Norton was excellent in his role as the Narrator. He so accurately resembled the average guy that it was scary. His voice has a perfect tone for narrating the story and he reminds me of a young Kevin Spacey. If only he gets better roles, he may very well go down a legend in Hollywood. Brad Pitt has always acted in likeable hero roles as well as \\"feel good\\" movies and he has managed to pull it off but in many of those roles, there was nothing special or extraordinary. In this movie, he was fantastic. I consider this to be his finest work together with his role as Det. Mills in Se7en. No one but him could've pulled of Tyler Durden. When he spoke, it just didn't sound written, it sounds authentic, the words come alive...like he really lives his life that way and it's what he truly believes. Any other person might have made it less exciting but Pitt nails it. And last but not least Helena Bonham Carter as Marla was also a really good choice. She did not have much screen time, but the times she does appear..she delivers with a fine performance.     There was a lot of bad publicity about this movie and although I admit this movie may not be for everyone, I loved it and so did most of my friends. I HIGHLY recommend this movie. This movie is not a renter, it's a keeper. It's movies like this that sets the bar higher for American cinema...seriously. And finally, as Tyler said \\"It's only after you've lost everything that you're free to do anything\\".

Having such a dubious association I was reluctant to view this film.  Having now seen it I can see my reticence was unfounded.  This is a gripping account of a talented teen, Jim Carroll(Leonardo DiCaprio), and his descent into the hell that is serious heroin addiction.  The film depicts how even the best of us can be insidiously seduced by our innate desire for kicks to try such a horribly addictive drug.  DiCaprio, who has since matured into one of our finer actors with his role in \\"The Aviator\\", shows early signs of the promise since fulfilled.  Mark Wahlberg is also good as Carroll's best friend who also falls into the heroin trap.  Good turns are provided by Lorraine Bracco as Jim's concerned mother and Ernie Hudson as Reggie, Jim's best friend even if he doesn't know it.  The film's biggest flaw is that ostensibly it's set in the sixties but it doesn't seem to have a feel for that era.

B0000CDLA7|1.0|Unfortunately, a very disappointing album which gives a clear indication of Dream Theaters decline artistically. Not being content with having given us the studio-improvised pretentiousness of Six Degrees of Inner Turbulence, Dream Theater, five professional musicians in their 30s and 40s, want to become angsty, heavy and dark. Unfortunately, they stopped being young and angry 20 years ago, and the result is laughably bad, devoid of any impact whatsoever. Solos are abundant, with clean precise picking and fast runs, but this listener feels nothing when he hears Dream Theaters studio indulgences and empty virtuosity. There is also little magic to be found in the harmonic minor heavy metal riffs John Petrucci churns out on his seven-string guitar, all following the same basic patterns of root note-transition-root note, often throwing in a bar or two in odd time signatures (so it can classify as \\"prog\\", like that should matter). <br /> <br />All that was magical about Dream Theater has vanished, a development starting with the appointment of Jordan Rudess as keyboardist. With this man behind the 'boards, all sense of restraint vanished and those that had given us such brilliant albums like Falling Into Infinity and Images and Words now went fully professional and started composing in the studio, instead of honing their compositions to the max in rehearsals. Train of Thought is clear evidence that DT are now releasing albums for the sake of releasing them, and is so mediocre that it marks the first album by said group that I have not, and will not, purchase.
B000001FA4|3.0|I cannot count how many times I have argued over the best U2 album ever made, only to be challenged by someone claiming \\"The Unforgettable Fire\\" as their best work.  I imagine that this is based on the fact that \\"Pride\\" is on this album as there are no other arguments that would be valid.  For me, this album is boring and lacks any character in depth of sound.  The absence of Steve Lillywhite is evident(as has been the case with the Dave Matthews Band).  While Eno and Lanois would go on to produce far more superior albums for U2 in later years, this project sounds like a rough draft more than a finished product.  I would have to place this album at the bottom of the U2 collection, I hardly ever pull this CD out to listen to it.  As the reviewer above states, you can listen to the best tracks from this CD live on \\"Rattle and Hum\\" in much better forms.
B000784WMW|4.0|I was pleased that they finally put this definitive version of Jane Eyre on DVD. All the episodes are there, with several scenes that I had never seen before, either during PBS broadcasts or on the older videotape release. The picture quality is excellent. The only negative is that each episode is broken up by running the end and beginning credits. On the older videotapes it ran like one long movie - definitely preferable. However, all in all, it is not too distracting, since the music is pleasant and it kind of reminded me of watching this originally twenty years ago on PBS. The only two places I really minded the breaks were in the bedroom fire scene and at the wedding.  <br /> <br />I continue to like the chemistry between the two leads in this version and the fact that the producers didn't wreck havoc with the original storyline or dialogue. This version continues to be the best out of all the releases of Jane Eyre ever made.
B00070DK5K|5.0|Criticisms of the sound and playing on this album are totally misplaced. It beats me how anyone could ever think that \\"music\\" could result from overlaying countless overdubs, played in the absence of the other musicians and on equipment barely louder than a sparrow chirp. This kind of living, breathing recording is standard in the jazz and classical worlds. What really makes the difference, however, is Michael Kamen's arrangements, which lift the music onto another plane -- compare the far less interesting -- and sonically much tamer -- versions on the original albums and the Ziggy live album. This applies particularly to the songs from the Ziggy studio album and Aladdin Sane, the originals of which are rather juvenile: in Michael Kamen's hands the atom is split and we are witness to a glorious explosion of musical potential, showing Bowie's true greatness (as does his magnificent singing). The incomparable band, too, really allows this music to take flight. I first bought this album when I was 12 years old, and I can see that it had a lasting influence, exposing me at an early age to music's unlimited possibilities: a typical day's listening today (I work at home) is likely to include Mahalia Jackson, Miles Davis, Bach, Weill, Haydn, Funkadelic, Ray Charles, Tom Waits, Ali Farka Toure and Bang on a Can. I feel I owe this freeing of perspectives partly to David Bowie and Michael Kamen. This album was the gateway.
B000000993|5.0|One of the best albums for this genre of the 20th century! With a strong theme for water throughout this album it is and always will be one of my own personal favorites. After the release of \\"opiate\\" (1st album) Tool was looking for their first full length album. With as much hard riffing, philosophy induced, fine tuned musical genious that we come to expect from TOOL it is still a hit now. \\"Sober\\" is one song that you can mention to even the most miniscule tool fan and expect one helluva reaction!  Prison sex, Flood, Swamp Song... these songs make it impossible for you to even think about anything else when it comes to music.  With the recent induction of Justin Chancellor to take over Paul D'Amour on bass guitar, Tool just gets better and better! Tell you what; If you can listen to \\"Sober\\" \\"Bottom\\" \\"Swamp Song\\" \\"Undertow\\" and not like Tool... congratulations, you need to be committed!
